body: @markusweimer Github seems to be up again. Do you want to take a look at my PR? It's all about debugging and readability; the fix itself is just setting the proper configuration

I've tested this change by running O.A.R.Examples.DriverRestart on an HDI cluster, and the job succeeded. Previously it got stuck because evaluators kept trying to connect to the driver, and driver kept rejecting them.
@markusweimer @shravanmn @dkm2110 This pull request have been open for two months without a single comment. Is there a discussion going on offline?
Good AppVeyor build: https://ci.appveyor.com/project/tcNickolas/reef/build/315-REEF-1648
Can you explain the deadlock in some more detail (either here or on the JIRA)? Under which circumstances do we have a deadlock between which locks?
LGTM, will test and merge.

Driver only sets evaluator to `SUBMITTED` if it actually submits task to it (which makes sense). 

On the first run of driver it submits a task to evaluator and switches it to `SUBMITTED`. After driver restart evaluator is initialized in `ALLOCATED` state, and driver doesn't set them to `SUBMITTED` again (because it doesn't submit task to old evaluator after restart). So evaluator contacts driver to report it's `RUNNING` and reconnect, and driver doesn't allow the transition.

> Driver only sets evaluator to `SUBMITTED` if it actually submits task to it (which makes sense).

Slight correction: It also sets it to `SUBMITTED` if only a root context was submitted to it.

True. But after restart driver doesn't submit either task or context to an evaluator which already has something running. Driver needs to accept heartbeat from evaluator first to figure out that this evaluator is still alive before it can decide whether it needs to submit something to it.

@markusweimer Splitting the issue into three:
- [REEF-1637](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1637) bugfix
- [REEF-1651](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1651) minor fixes and logging improvements that helped to debug the issue  [REEF-1637](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1637)
-  [REEF-1649](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1649) more logging improvements to debug clean REEF Driver shutdown

PRs will follow shortly

First lock is on `DriverIdleManager`
Second lock is on `ResourceManagerStatus`

`DriverIdleManager.onPotentiallyIdle()` is the code path which triggers driver shutdown once all "idleness sources" report idle. 

There are three idleness sources and three matching places in code which call `onPotentiallyIdle()`: 
- clock (just periodic checks), 
- resource manager (checks for idleness once there are no container requests and no allocated containers), and
- event handlers (checks for idleness if all evaluators are closed).

`onPotentiallyIdle()` aquires lock on `DriverIdleManager` and proceeds to check all sources for idleness, during which phase it 
calls `ResourceManagerStatus.isIdle()` and aquires lock on `ResourceManagerStatus`. 

Checks from clock and from event handlers call `onPotentiallyIdle()` without any extra locks. But 
`ResourceManagerStatus` calls `onPotentiallyIdle()` from `onRMRunning()` which itself aquires lock on `ResourceManagerStatus` first.

Each of these code paths is executed in a separate thread. PR #1007 which was our initial suspect just moved the check from event handlers into a separate thread, so even before that there were two threads. 
Deadlock would occur if call from `ResourceManagerStatus` competes with one of the other calls 
(that's why deadlock frequency increased after #1007 - the checks from resource manager and from event handlers occur very close in time to each other, and previously the check only competed with the clock). 

The fix removes the lock from `onRMRunning()`, so that all checks don't hold any extra locks before calling `onPotentiallyIdle()`.
Reopened as PR #1167

Here is the call flows:
**EvaluatorManager->Close**
       --------------
    scheduleAlarm for calling the following:  YARNResourceReleaseHandler.onNext(finalResourceReleaseEventresourceReleaseEvent)
        YarnContainerManager.release(finalStringcontainerId)
            ->removeFromContainers
            ->Remove from RM
            ->updateRuntimeStatus()
                REEFEventHandlers.onRuntimeStatus(finalRuntimeStatusEventruntimeStatusEvent)
                ResourceManagerStatus.onNext(finalRuntimeStatusEventruntimeStatusEvent)
                ResourceManagerStatus.onRMRunning(finalRuntimeStatusEventruntimeStatusEvent) --- **synchronized** 
                    if(this.**isIdle**()){
                    this.driverIdleManager.get().**onPotentiallyIdle**(IDLE_MESSAGE);
                    }
    -------------  
    Original thread:
    EvaluatorIdlenessThreadPool.runCheckAsync(finalEvaluatorManagermanager)->
    EvaluatorManager.checkIdlenessSource()->
    EventHandlerIdlenessSource.check()->
    DriverIdleManager.**onPotentiallyIdle**(finalIdleMessagereason)->
    DriverIdlenessSource.getIdleStatus()->    ----- the log shows it stuck at this line forever until I killed the application. 
    DriverIdlenessSource.**isIdle**()
LGTM as they are all public get.  @markusweimer you might want to look at it.
When the driver is restarted, should the existing evaluator state is initialized to the previous state? It could be ALLOCATED or SUBMITTED depending on when the driver was down, right?
@markusweimer  if you could have a quick look that would be great.

> The presence of the new interface IJobCancelledDetector suggests a polling system to detect cancellation. Shouldn't it be event-driven all the way?

Need to close on this before making other changes.
The driver design is still event driven (IObserver<IJobCancelled>) .
But yes, there is pull implementation as well.
I added JobLifecycleManager class which essentially pulls cancellation signal from IJobCancellationDetector on timer.
Main reason I added it into driver project because, (imho) most of the clients will use external dependencies to detect cancellation and will want to implement some kind of pulling anyway, so this class makes implementation easier on the client side. Also this timer-based lifecycle manager could be useful to implement other scenarios in driver. For instance: job suspend/resume, stage timeouts ((hence generic name for the class)).
if we want keep driver configuration to be purely event driven, this implementation can be moved to the client: we can expose Observable<IJobCancelled> in the job definition and have client do the pulling implementation.
Thoughts?

/Andrey

How would driver after restart know what driver before restart did? We're only storing container allocations and deallocations, not every event of evaluator lifetime. We shouldn't store every event for performance reasons, since we're writing every change to DFS, and we haven't yet done performance testing on real scenarios to see how much overhead it introduces. And even if we wrote every event, it's possible that one of the writes will fail, which would lead us to exactly the same situation as we're seeing now.

I consider the check for allowed transitions as something to prohibit "backwards" transitions, like from completed to running, not to impose extra restrictions on "forward" transitions.

Let's put comments so that we know why we allow this transition. 

For more extensive level of driver fault tolerant, I believe there will be a lot of more scenarios to cover. Or it can be left to the driver.
I've added a comment to describe the scenario in which such transition can occur.
LGTM, will test and merge.

I'm not sure I completely understand, but: Can't we introduce a lock for the idleness checks? That way, only one of the code paths to `onPotentiallyIdle` can be active at a time and we don't run the risk of introducing new race conditions. Or am I missing the point?

`onPotentiallyIdle` already has a dedicated lock for it (as a synchronized method), I don't think adding any extra locks will help :-) On the contrary, we need to remove lock acquisition outside `onPotentiallyIdle` so that it can't deadlock with the lock acquired inside it.

Marria is right. now the issue is nested locks causes the dead lock. We need to remove unnecessary locks to break down the method calls so that to avoid dead lock instead of the other way round. 
I can show you the code path for details if you would like.
@tcNickolas We had some discussions around when this was opened, but now this is a bit inactive. I'll close this for now.
OK, I will test and merge.
I merged this, but our github mirror seems to be behind.
@andrey-me Is it ready for review or you will split it into multiple JIRA?
Weird, this change is not large enough to block our mirror. We should merge some other change on top of this one to unblock - very carefully :-) I'll close this for now
@markusweimer What do you think about the change now? I really don't think we need another lock here
@motus Did you test this with `O.A.R.Examples.DriverRestart`? I'd be very cautious around anything driver restart-related, since we don't have proper tests for it yet

@markusweimer good points, and I really don't know the right answers. We create threads in many different ways (Wake thread factories, Java executors, timers, standalone threads...), and I could not come up with an elegant way of managing all that zoo. That is, I opted for the least invasive fix that would help me to debug the main issue - a clean shutdown.

I think we can come back to the thread naming/management question later (I have a JIRA opened just for that) and implement a proper centralized solution.
@tcNickolas Could you please try that? My VisualStudio is a mess and I am currently updating it 😞

removed optional config code as well, replaced with EmptyConfig initialization instead

Is this expected?

@markusweimer it is expected - we are trying to close the acceptor that has already been closed, hence the error. Maybe we can downgrade it to a warning again? :smiley:

Anyway, I was meant to open another JIRA to describe that condition to double check if we close the same transport more than once. Meanwhile, I think the most important thing is to keep the `.close()` method idempotent.
@motus Fair enough. Tests still pass, so I will go ahead with the merge.

addressed all comments now. ready for next review.

OK folks, here's a new iteration of the change. We now use `{{...}}`  syntax when building path for the remote java binary on the client. When the job is submitted, Hadoop performs that expansion for us; in local mode, I've implemented that expansion in the `RunnableProcess` class in REEF. @markusweimer could you please take a look? Thanks!

addressed all comments. ready for next review cycle.

2 main changes:
- lifecycle manager starts/stops timer based on subscriber count (not on driver started event)
- added fun test based on BroadcastReduce tests.

Since I am not that familiar with the C#, I am looking for the following feedback:
1. Organization (where the code goes and so on) and configuration for the "Checkpoint" project
2. Good alternatives to use instead of `System.IO.Stream`. On the Java side we use NIO channels, but I haven't found any immediate C# equivalent . We should at least differentiate between read- and write- only streams just as the Java checkpoint service does.

And of course any other comments you may have :)

@markusweimer 

> There are many methods in internal classes that are marked public. Shouldn't they also be internal?

As said above, if the class is marked internal all its methods and properties are internal even if they are marked public. I was looking at web and one school of thought is to make them public, since later in case we change the class to public we do not need to modify each and every member.

> All classes inheriting from ImmutableMetricsImpl inherit functionality, not just interfaces. I generally prefer composition over behavior inheritance. Would that be an option here?

It is a possibility but at the expense of repetitive code in `ImmutableCounter`, Gauges etc. For composition, I have to introduce `ImmutableMetricsImpl` as the variable in these classes while they will directly inherit `IImmutableMetrics`. Then in all the functions of all the classes with the exception of `Visit` function we will simply call the underlying functions in `ImmutableMetricsImpl`. AFAIK, composition is preferred over inheritance where we see that dynamic binding and polymorphism related issues can exist in future. I do not see that happening here.

Let me know if you think otherwise. 

> We at some point decided not to use inner classes for parameters. Instead, move them to a Parameters namespace.

Can you elaborate on this? I did not quite get the comment.

> It would be good to have a simple example REEF program which uses the metrics system.

Will do.

Comments for project configuration:
- Please add license to `AssemblyInfo.cs` and `O.A.R.IO.Checkpoint.csproj` - this is what failing Travis build tries to tell you :-)
- We shouldn't have "Microsoft" in `AssemblyInfo.cs` company and copyright sections, as we're an Apache project.
- This project also needs two other targets imported in `.csproj`, `$(SolutionDir)\.nuget\NuGet.targets` and `$(PackagesDir)\StyleCop.MSBuild.$(StyleCopVersion)\build\StyleCop.MSBuild.Targets` (and probably StyleCop package together with them in `packages.config`). You can see examples in all other projects.

Actually, could you check existing `.csproj` files and make the newly created one as similar to them as possible? There are a lot of other differences in your file, like using `v4.5.2` for `TargetFrameworkVersion` (we use `v4.5`), having `Configuration` and `Platform` tags, not using `build.props`, having conditioned property groups etc. We want this part of project configuration to be as uniform as possible, so that we don't run into issues when modifying something in the build process in the future.
@markusweimer regarding REEF program for MetricsSystem, shall we do it as part of this PR or separate one?

Regarding the inheritance vs. composition: Please make sure that all inheriting classes are `sealed`. Also, if possible, make the parent class `internal`. That way we at least protect us from users of the code to use inheritance.

> > We at some point decided not to use inner classes for parameters. Instead, move them to a Parameters namespace.
> 
> Can you elaborate on this? I did not quite get the comment.

There are some cases where named parameters are defined as classes within other classes ("inner classes"). The way the names of those inner classes are encoded is different between Java and C#. Hence, we decided not to use inner classes for named parameters. Instead, create a Namespace `Parameters` for them.

> regarding REEF program for MetricsSystem, shall we do it as part of this PR or separate one?

New PR is fine.
@motus Please have a review. Thanks!

> There are some cases where named parameters are defined as classes within other classes ("inner classes"). 

So if I understand correctly, each parameter name and corresponding class should not be part of any other class and directly be part of Parameters namespace. For example, if there is some logical grouping of parameters we should not do so by putting them in one class?
I completed this pass.
@motus I have addressed your review comments.
@markusweimer Would you like to review it?

> So if I understand correctly, each parameter name and corresponding class should not be part of any other class and directly be part of Parameters namespace. For example, if there is some logical grouping of parameters we should not do so by putting them in one class?

You can group them into sub-namespaces. But not within classes. we have namespaces like `O.A.R.Driver.Parameters`, for instance.
@markusweimer @jwang98052 @tcNickolas  I have incorporated the comments. Please have a look.
Also, do you thin we should try splitting this PR?
If there is a way to split this PR into smaller ones which are logically complete, it would be great. I'll try to review this change, but with 49 files it starts to look daunting :-)
@tcNickolas @markusweimer Please start reviewing this instead of REEF-1543.
Closing this. Will split over multiple PRs.
Updated as per @tcNickolas comments

@dkm2110 Do you have technical design document for Metrics? What each API is designed for? What they are supposed to do? What are the definition of Gauge, Tag, Rate, Stat, Metrics, Record, how they are related? What is the role of visitor? Why mutable/immutable are introduced here? I just have some difficulty to understand the code at the abstract level before it is associated to any REEF metrics. May be I missed some discussions before. A document or an overview with us would be welcome. Thanks!

Two more comments: 
1. Please add `packages.config` file for `StyleCop.MSBuild` package. Otherwise if somebody deletes their packages and tries to build this project alone, the package won't be downloaded.
2. The changes to `Org.Apache.REEF.sln` which Github ignores are actually pretty massive. We should not accidentally update version of Visual Studio or introduce configuration to include `Any CPU`. Please edit this file to include only the necessary changes.
Also, please do check results of CI builds when they fail. After StyleCop is configured for this project, it actually fails build :-)
+1 on this change. However, wouldn't it be even better to share _one_ `AssemblyInfo.cs` across all projects to make it impossible for future divergence?
But each assembly has different title and description which cannot be shared. Unless we can split the context to do partial sharing.

It would be better but it takes time to figure out how to do it, since part of the fields shouldn't be shared. Right now I wanted to unify shared values to use so that newly created projects (#1181) would use correct values and not introduce more divergence right now.
@tcNickolas @jwang98052 @markusweimer  I have addressed the review comments.
